name: Hypophosphatemic Osteomalacia with Tertiary Hyperparathyroidism
chief_complaint: Persistent bone pain and muscle weakness for several months, worsening fatigue
symptoms: chronic bone pain (especially in hips and legs)
physical_findings: tenderness on palpation of long bones
positive Gower's sign (difficulty rising from seated position)
treatment: possible parathyroidectomy if tertiary hyperparathyroidism persists
prognosis: Variable; requires lifelong management. Bone pain and muscle weakness typically improve with treatment, but complete resolution is uncommon. Risk of progressive renal impairment due to nephrocalcinosis.
description: A complex metabolic bone disorder characterized by renal phosphate wasting due to elevated FGF23, leading to osteomalacia. The condition is complicated by autonomous parathyroid hormone secretion (tertiary hyperparathyroidism) developing secondary to chronic hypocalcemia and vitamin D deficiency. This creates a challenging therapeutic paradox where treating the osteomalacia may exacerbate the hyperparathyroidism.
risk_factors: tumor-induced osteomalacia (though none detected in this case)
